fields.public_field_1_en: You're walking to work from the bus stop when your phone rings. It's the director of the town's affordable housing developer
John, the affordable Housing Non-profit Director
fields.public_field_2_en: Hi Mayor! The local university just released a report on the future of housing costs in Bayville. Did you know that by 2050, the average family in our town will spend almost half of their income on housing?
fields.public_field_3_en: That’s concerning. We need to do something right now.

fields.public_field_1_en: How are you going to prevent that from happening?

fields.public_field_2_en: Fund affordable housing production and preservation
fields.public_field_3_en: Raise taxes to generate funds to build a broad range of permanently affordable housing.
fields.public_field_4_en: This would provide a regular stream of funds to address the need for affordable housing.
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Strategy 1 pros
fields.public_field_5_en: Opponents say that taxes raise the cost of living for everyone and that other funding sources should be used.
fields.public_field_8_en: Require 20 percent of all new housing to be affordable
fields.public_field_9_en: Adopt regulations that require twenty percent of all newly constructed units to be rented at below-market rents.
fields.public_field_10_en: This provides a growing supply of affordable housing that is distributed throughout the region.
fields.public_field_11_en: Opponents say this strategy could limit the total amount of housing that is built by increasing the costs to developers.
fields.public_field_15_en: Implement a suite of renter protection strategies to prevent large rent increases and protect tenants from discrimination by landlords.
fields.public_field_16_en: This strategy would promote more affordable rents and greater stability for renters.
fields.public_field_17_en: Opponents say renter protections could cause some landlords to stop renting out their properties, reducing the overall housing supply.

fields.public_field_1_en: fund affordable housing production and preservation!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to produce between 400 and 600 new permanently affordable rental units each year. That’s around 11,000 to 17,000 units between now and 2050. Thousands more already affordable units were maintained and remained affordable.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other housing issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: require 20 percent of all new housing to be affordable!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to produce between 2,400 and 4,000 new permanently affordable rental units each year. That’s around 70,000 to 100,000 units between now and 2050. However, this policy only improved affordability for those that were able to move to these new units and did not help people afford to stay in their existing homes.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other housing issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: increase renter protections!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: A similar set of policies implemented in Portland, Oregon capped annual rent increases at 2% and resulted in a fifteen percent decrease in no-fault evictions.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other housing issues. Don’t spent too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spend> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: Your housing plan is almost complete! The final item is choosing a strategy to guide infill development on vacant or underutilized properties throughout the city. Your next stop is the Citizens’ Advisory Council meeting, where you will hear about two proposals for infill development in your city.
Resident 1
fields.public_field_2_en: Our city owns some land that is currently sitting vacant, with no plans for future use. Since we already own that land, building housing there would be cheaper and faster than if we had to find a site and buy it first. We could build there ourselves or sell the land to an affordable housing developer.
fields.public_field_3_en: See what __ has to say

fields.public_field_1_en: Resident 2
fields.public_field_2_en: There are several malls around town that have seen better days. Storefronts have been empty for months, and it is only going to get worse as more people choose to shop online. We could work with the mall owners to turn these sites into vibrant neighborhoods with a mix of housing, workplaces, and shops!
fields.public_field_3_en: Those are both interesting ideas!

fields.public_field_1_en: Which sites would you prioritize for reuse and redevelopment?
fields.public_field_2_en: Repurpose public land to build housing
fields.public_field_3_en: Pass state legislation to reduce the barriers to development for housing on vacant and underused public land.
fields.public_field_4_en: This land could be developed by cities or sold to developers under the condition that a certain number of affordable units are built or certain amenities are provided.
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Strategy 1 pros
fields.public_field_5_en: Opponents say that selling public land is potentially risky and could make it more difficult to build other public facilities like parks or schools to meet future demand.
fields.public_field_9_en: Work with cities and property owners to redevelop vacant and under-performing shopping centers into mixed-income neighborhoods.
fields.public_field_10_en: This land could be acquired for a lower-cost and is often located near existing public transportation.
fields.public_field_11_en: Opponents say the number of potential sites is too small to fully address the need for new housing.

fields.public_field_1_en: repurpose public land to build housing!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to produce between 1,000 and 2,000 new homes each year. While this covers just a small fraction of the projected need for new housing in the region, these new homes tend to be more affordable than the average home in the region.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other housing issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: transform aging malls into neighborhoods!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to produce between 3,000 and 6,000 new homes per year. Additionally, new stores and other workplaces in the new neighborhoods are expected to employ almost twice as many people as were employed when the malls were in operation.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other housing issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: You hang up the phone and check your notifications. There’s a healthy debate happening on social media right now about housing policy in the neighboring town.
MoreHousingMoreRiders
fields.public_field_2_en: Transit and higher density housing make sense together.
fields.public_field_3_en: We should change current zoning regulations to make it possible to build duplexes and apartments within walking distance of transit, instead of single-family houses.
fields.public_field_4_en: Existing homes wouldn’t necessarily be rebuilt, but it gives property owners the option.
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: User 1 message 3
fields.public_field_6_en: Some neighborhoods in Bayville have better schools, more parks, and better transportation options.
fields.public_field_7_en: Unfortunately, these same neighborhoods tend to have high housing costs, meaning only those that can afford to live there have access to these opportunities.
fields.public_field_8_en: If we allowed for more affordable housing in these neighborhoods, people of all walks of life could have the chance to benefit from these resources.
fields.public_field_13_en: These ideas could work for Bayville!

fields.public_field_1_en: Which policy would you choose to guide future development in your town?
Which policy would you choose to guide future development in your town?
fields.public_field_2_en: Allow affordable housing in high resource areas
fields.public_field_3_en: Allow for the construction of mixed-income housing in high-opportunity areas - places with quality schools or other resources linked to better life outcomes.
fields.public_field_4_en: This could connect more low- and moderate-income families to these resources and in turn improve life outcomes.
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Strategy 1 pros
fields.public_field_5_en: Opponents say building affordable housing in high-opportunity areas is expensive and would result in a smaller number of affordable housing units being built overall.
fields.public_field_8_en: Allow diverse housing around transit stops
fields.public_field_9_en: Pass state legislation requiring areas within a 10-minute walk of any rail station to be rezoned to allow for apartments and duplexes.
fields.public_field_10_en: This could provide more people with access to transit while also generating ridership for the rail system.
fields.public_field_11_en: Opponents say luxury development near rail stations would increase nearby housing costs and could result in displacement of lower-income residents.

fields.public_field_1_en:
You selected allow affordable housing in high resource areas!
Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to produce affordable housing for between 100 and 400 households each year within high resource neighborhoods.
While this represents a relatively small share of all new affordable units, residents of these neighborhoods may expect to benefit from a lack of concentrated poverty and easier access to amenities like parks and quality schools. Unfortunately, this policy is unpopular with some residents of those high resource neighborhoods, which could hurt your chances of re-election next term.
fields.public_field_2_en: Allow affordable housing in high resource areas
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: Next

fields.public_field_1_en:
You selected allow diverse housing around transit stops!
Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to produce housing for between 20,000 and 40,000 households located within a ten minute walk of frequent transit service.
Building housing close to transit is likely to have a number of secondary benefits, including decreases in individual transportation costs and greenhouse gas emissions from transportation.
However, a group of people that already lived close to transit stops have written to you to express concerns that they will be displaced by luxury development and rising housing costs on their blocks.
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: Next

fields.public_field_1_en: You get to your office and sit down at your desk. You hear a knock at the door - it’s the planning commissioner here for your monthly meeting. Today’s topic: policies to influence the location of jobs.

fields.public_field_2_en: Over time, parts of our city have become primarily residential, while jobs have concentrated in neighborhoods around downtown. Every morning, waves of workers travel from the residential neighborhoods to their workplaces downtown, resulting in traffic congestion and crowded buses and trains. If more neighborhoods had a mix of jobs and housing, peak commute periods would be less hectic.
fields.public_field_3_en: Go to your economy plan!

fields.public_field_1_en: Which approach would you take to address the mismatch of jobs and housing?

fields.public_field_2_en: Place office caps in jobs-rich locations
fields.public_field_3_en: Limit the number of new office buildings that can be built each year in areas with many more jobs than residents.
fields.public_field_4_en: This could make office space in high-demand areas more expensive, encouraging other employers to seek cheaper land or rents elsewhere within the region.
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Strategy 1 pros
fields.public_field_5_en: Placing a limit on where office space can be built could lead to some employers moving out of the city.
fields.public_field_8_en: Create incubator program in economically challenged neighborhoods
fields.public_field_9_en: Provide resources to support the creation of businesses by low- and moderate-income people in communities with limited job opportunities.
fields.public_field_10_en: This strategy could spur economic activity, create jobs, and keep wealth circulating within the economically challenged communities.
fields.public_field_11_en: Small businesses need time to grow and mature before they can provide a substantial number of jobs.

fields.public_field_1_en: place office caps in jobs-rich locations!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: New office developments are starting to pop up in residential areas. However, some businesses have threatened to move jobs to a neighboring city where offices are cheaper, leading residents to worry this policy could damage the local economy. Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to increase the number of jobs in predominantly residential areas by XX percent and increase the amount of new home construction in employment centers by XX percent by 2050, leading to a more balanced distribution of homes and jobs.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other economic issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: create incubator program in economically challenged neighborhoods!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: New incubators are opening in communities around the city. While most new businesses have just a few employees for now, several businesses have grown rapidly. These growing businesses are hiring new employees and doing business in their communities, which has benefitted other local shops. Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to increase the number of overall jobs in economically challenged communities from XXX to XXX by 2050, more than doubling total employment in these areas which have previously seen few job opportunities for residents.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other economic issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: You have a full schedule today, which means you are on your way to work early. As you wait for your train, your phone starts buzzing. It looks like one of your posts seeking input for the economy plan has gone viral!
BackToWork
fields.public_field_2_en: Many working parents can’t afford childcare and have to put their careers on hold because of it.
fields.public_field_3_en: If we provided low-cost childcare to low-income families, parents would have the option to return to work or school if they wanted, without having to weigh the costs of childcare
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: DO NOT USE
fields.public_field_6_en: With a growing population like ours, we need to build more housing and maintain our infrastructure.
fields.public_field_7_en: We don’t have enough trained people to fill the construction jobs we have today, much less meet the increased demand in the future.
fields.public_field_8_en: Investing in training the construction workforce will help us keep up and will provide more middle-wage jobs.
fields.public_field_10_en: Many people in our city today are part-time or freelance workers.
fields.public_field_11_en: They like the flexibility, but most of these jobs don’t provide benefits like health insurance the way many full-time jobs do.
fields.public_field_12_en: We should require employers to pay for a fair share of worker benefits.

fields.public_field_1_en: Which workforce policy do you want to implement?

fields.public_field_2_en: Provide portable benefits for part-time and freelance workers
fields.public_field_3_en: Pass state legislation requiring companies that rely on part-time or freelance workers to contribute benefits in proportion to the hours worked.
fields.public_field_4_en: This would reduce the costs of obtaining insurance for thousands of part-time or freelance workers
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Strategy 1 pros
fields.public_field_5_en: Businesses that rely on part-time or freelance workers could choose to employ fewer people, automate jobs, or move away entirely, reducing the total number of jobs in the city.
fields.public_field_8_en: Expand childcare support for low-income families
fields.public_field_9_en: Provide reduced cost childcare for low-income families, enabling parents to return to work or attend school without worrying about the cost of childcare.
fields.public_field_10_en: This strategy would allow thousands of parents to return to work or school and would benefit children through education and socialization.
fields.public_field_11_en: Providing safe, high quality childcare can be expensive. Costs to operate this program could increase substantially in the future if many families choose to participate.
fields.public_field_15_en: Partner with neighboring cities and the construction industry to provide training programs, apprenticeships, and financial incentives that prepare workers for middle-wage construction-related jobs.
fields.public_field_16_en: This would address the current deficit in the construction workforce, training the workers needed to build new housing and maintain infrastructure.
fields.public_field_17_en: This program could be seen as subsidizing the training costs of privately-owned construction companies

fields.public_field_1_en: provide portable benefits for part-time and freelance workers!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: Companies that hire part-time or freelance workers now contribute to their workers’ insurance costs based on the number of hours worked. Without this strategy, these workers would have had to pay the full cost of benefits out of pocket or risk being uninsured. Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to benefit XXX part-time or freelance workers each year.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other economic issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: expand childcare support for low-income families!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: Families are already enrolling their children, and new workers are returning to the labor force. Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to enable XXX additional people this year to join the workforce and XXX additional people to enroll in higher education. Women would especially benefit from this strategy - with XX percent of the new workers and students being women.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other economic issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: expand construction workforce programs!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: There is a line out the door to sign up for training programs at the local community college! New trainees are excited to learn a new trade and enter the construction workforce. Many of these new positions will be middle-wage jobs that do not require a college degree, providing new pathways to economic opportunity. Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to increase the number of construction jobs from XXX to XXX by 2050, more than doubling total employment in the industry.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other economic issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: You get back to your office after the community meeting. Suddenly, everything starts to shake. This time, it was just a small tremor - no major damage to report. However, it has started a conversation online about how the city should respond to the threat of a major earthquake.
LomaPrieta1989
fields.public_field_2_en: Geologists say the next major earthquake is likely to happen by the year 2050.
fields.public_field_3_en: The city needs to buy a disaster recovery bond that would provide us with funds to start rebuilding right away, without having to wait for federal assistance.
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: DO NOT USE
fields.public_field_6_en: An earthquake could destroy thousands of homes and other buildings.
fields.public_field_7_en: What our city needs is a low-interest loan program that homeowners could use to retrofit their homes and reduce their risk of damage before the next earthquake strikes.
fields.public_field_8_en: Landlords could use the fund to improve their properties, too!

fields.public_field_1_en: Which strategy would you add to your environment plan to prepare for a future earthquake?

fields.public_field_2_en: Purchase disaster recovery financing to recover after disasters
fields.public_field_3_en: Purchase a catastrophe bond that would provide funds for recovery in the event of a disaster like an earthquake or wildfire.
fields.public_field_4_en: Disaster financing funds could be ready quickly and would shorten the amount of time it takes to rebuild.
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Strategy 1 pros
fields.public_field_5_en: This strategy does not do anything to protect damage from occurring
fields.public_field_8_en: Expand financing for energy, water, seismic, fire, and accessibility improvements
fields.public_field_9_en: Provide low-cost loans to owners of existing homes and commercial buildings to upgrade their properties to better withstand natural disasters.
fields.public_field_10_en: This strategy reduces the number of homes lost to earthquake damage
fields.public_field_11_en: This strategy largely benefits homeowners that have the resources to make these upgrades, leaving out renters and lower-income homeowners.

fields.public_field_1_en: purchase disaster recovery financing to recover after disasters!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: With the disaster fund, you can breathe easy knowing that you will have the resources to rebuild in the event of an earthquake. However, the bond does not reduce the amount of damage that occurs, meaning life in your city could still be significantly disrupted. Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to increase the rate of housing production after a simulated major earthquake from XXX homes per year to XXX homes per year.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other environmental issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: expand financing for energy, water, seismic, fire, and accessibility improvements!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: Homeowners and landlords have already started to renovate their buildings. The projected number of homes lost to earthquake damage decreases with every building that is retrofitted. Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to decrease the number of homes destroyed in the event of a major earthquake from XXX to XXX and would likely reduce the number of deaths and injuries as well.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other housing issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: You are taking a walk through the park when you see the local environmental advocacy organization setting up for a rally. You walk over and strike up a conversation with one of the volunteers.

fields.public_field_2_en: Our city’s population is projected to continue growing between now and 2050. That means more people will be using our parks and natural spaces every day. We want to accommodate these new visitors while also maintaining our parks, trails, and greenways in good condition. We need to pass a measure to generate new revenue for maintenance and new facilities. Do you think you could include this in your plan?
fields.public_field_3_en: Go to your environment plan!

fields.public_field_1_en: Do you support this proposal, or would you rather save your budget to address other environmental challenges?

fields.public_field_2_en: Pass a regional measure for parks, trails, and greenways
fields.public_field_3_en: Pass a regional funding measure to generate new money for open space preservation, recreational trails, and wildlife corridors.
fields.public_field_4_en: This strategy would provide funding to expand maintenance as the population grows, protecting parks and recreation areas from overuse and opening new facilities where possible.
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Strategy 1 pros
fields.public_field_5_en: The regional measure would have to be paid back using funds from new taxes and fees or from the general fund.

fields.public_field_1_en: pass a regional measure for parks, trails, and greenways
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: You selected pass a regional measure for parks, trails, and greenways! TBD, depends on how policy will be evaluated
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other environmental issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: FILL IN
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: FILL IN
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other environmental issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: Now that you have made your decision on the funding measure, it is time to head to your next meeting of the day. You have a community meeting at your city’s beachside neighborhood, where residents will be discussing sea level rise.
Resident 1
fields.public_field_2_en: Sea levels are projected to rise between 1 and 3 feet over the next 30 years. This could flood roads and homes in our city’s coastal communities. Personally, I think we need to adapt all of our coastal communities to sea level rise to prevent flooding. We have a number of tools to use: marsh restoration, levees, and sea walls, to name a few!
fields.public_field_3_en: See what __ has to say

fields.public_field_1_en: Resident 2
fields.public_field_2_en: I agree that sea level rise is a major threat, and I wish we could fully adapt to sea level rise as well. Unfortunately, some places are not easy to protect, and it would cost a lot to make a small difference. I say we partially adapt to sea level rise, agreeing to let some places flood when the cost does not justify the benefit.
fields.public_field_3_en: See what __ has to say

fields.public_field_1_en: Resident 3
fields.public_field_2_en: Sea level rise is already affecting our community. There’s a highway north of town that already floods during heavy rains. It’s not located in the most populous part of town, but I still think we should direct our money toward fixing that problem first.
fields.public_field_3_en: Those are both interesting ideas!

fields.public_field_1_en: How will you plan to adapt to sea level rise?

fields.public_field_2_en: Partially adapt to sea level rise
fields.public_field_3_en: Use marsh restoration, levees, and sea walls to protect the parts of the community most vulnerable to sea level rise, accepting that difficult to protect areas will eventually be flooded.
fields.public_field_4_en: This strategy targets resources at the easiest to protect areas.
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Strategy 1 pros
fields.public_field_5_en: This strategy only protects some communities, leaving around 25 percent of vulnerable land area to be flooded.
fields.public_field_8_en: Fully adapt to sea level rise
fields.public_field_9_en: Use marsh restoration, levees, and sea walls to protect all at-risk communities from up to three feet of sea level rise.
fields.public_field_10_en: All communities are protected from up to three feet of sea level rise.
fields.public_field_11_en: Protecting the remaining 25 percent of communities is much more expensive than the first 75 percent.
fields.public_field_14_en: Adapt a highway to sea level rise
fields.public_field_15_en: Adapt one highway which is frequently flooded by rains and forecasted to be permanently closed due to flooding by the year 2050, like Highway 37 in the North Bay.
fields.public_field_16_en: Adapting the road to sea level rise would address the flooding problem that currently exists, while the other strategies protect areas that are not yet affected by flooding.
fields.public_field_17_en: This is one of the lesser-used highways in a lower-density part of the community, meaning relatively few people use it.

fields.public_field_1_en: partially adapt to sea level rise!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: Your team immediately springs to action, planting marshes and installing levees and sea walls in strategic locations. Unfortunately, residents living in an area that will remain unprotected are unhappy with the policy and are calling for your removal. Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to decrease the number of flooded homes from  XXX to XXX by 2050, with over XXX acres protected from flooding if the sea level were to rise up to three feet.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other environmental issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: fully adapt to sea level rise!
fields.public_field_2_en: Fully adapt to sea level rise
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: Your team knows that protecting all threatened areas from sea level rise will be a challenge, but they come up with a plan and get to work implementing it. Unfortunately, some residents are upset with the cost of the project and are calling on you to cut back the project scope. Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to decrease the number of flooded homes from  XXX to 0 by 2050, with over XXX acres protected from flooding if the sea level were to rise up to three feet.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other environmental issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: adapt a key highway to sea level rise!
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.
fields.public_field_3_en: Residents are pleased to see construction crews at work on the at-risk highway. However, usage has been lower than anticipated, meaning the cost per user is high compared to other projects. Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area on State Route 37, which connects Solano and Marin counties, would prevent this corridor from flooding in the event of sea level rise up to three feet. Without this strategy, average travel times for North Bay residents are expected to increase from XX minutes to XX minutes by 2050, as travelers are forced to find more indirect routes around the flooded roadway. While the strategy has a specific geographic focus, its effects could reduce traffic on nearby roads as well.
fields.public_field_4_en: Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other environmental issues. Don’t spend too much!
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Remaining budget. <coins_spent> and <coins_left> are available variables

fields.public_field_1_en: Welcome to Bayville
fields.public_field_2_en: Bayville is a fictional mid-sized city in the very real Bay Area. It’s a great place to live, but life here does have its challenges.
fields.public_field_3_en: Let's start.

fields.public_field_1_en: Bayville has challenges
fields.public_field_2_en: Traffic congestion, housing affordability, a declining share of jobs in middle-wage industries, and neighborhoods at risk of sea level rise are all problems facing the residents today.
fields.public_field_3_en: That sounds familiar.

fields.public_field_1_en: The future is uncertain
fields.public_field_2_en: In the future, residents may also be confronted with damage from a major earthquake, experience a global economic recession, or witness the widespread adoption of self-driving cars.
fields.public_field_3_en: I’m intrigued.

fields.public_field_1_en: Congratulations
fields.public_field_2_en:
How will Bayville prepare for the future that lies ahead?
That’s up to you!
You were just elected mayor.
fields.public_field_3_en: Wow, I’m honored.

fields.public_field_1_en: Your challenge
fields.public_field_2_en:
As mayor, you will develop a long-range plan that charts the course for housing, transportation, environmental resilience, and economic development for your town through the year 2050.
You'll receive policy proposals from advisors and helpful residents and choose your top priorities.
fields.public_field_3_en: Bring it on!

fields.public_field_1_en: Instructions
fields.public_field_2_en: You'll have a budget of 100 coins for each of the four topic areas, representing the cost and political difficulty of enacting each policy. Be careful not to go over budget!
fields.public_field_3_en: Let's start.

fields.public_field_1_en: One more thing before we start...
fields.public_field_2_en: Please answer a few questions so that we can better understand who our new mayor is.
fields.public_field_3_en: What should we call you?
fields.public_field_4_en: Where do you live?
fields.public_field_4_meta_description: Second question
